learningContent.title: Adding tables to a concept topic

lcInstruction.p: There are two elements available for creating tables in a concept topic: <simpletable> and <table>.

Simple tables are used to present information in a very basic tabular format. Tables are much more flexible in their ability to display information and allow for more complex tabular structures. For example, the <simpletable> element does not allow for titles, spanned cells, or footer rows, while <table> supports all of these features and more.
The elements contained in the <simpletable> element include:

li.p: <sthead>, the container element for the header row of a <simpletable> element. The <sthead> element contains the <stentry> element and is optional. There can only be one <sthead> element in a <simpletable> element.
<strow>, the container element for the body rows of a <simpletable> element. The <strow> element contains the <stentry> element. A <simpletable> element can have one or more <strow> elements.

, the container element for a single cell in a element. The element contains the text of a cell in the element, which should be wrapped in a

element according to best practice.

lcInstruction.p: The elements contained in the <table> element include:

li.p: <title>, the container element for the text of a <table> elementâ€™s title or caption. A <table> element can only contain one <title> element.

<tgroup>, the container element for the main content of a <table> element. The <tgroup> element contains the <colspec>, <thead>, and <tbody> elements. A <table> element can contain one or more <tgroup> elements.

<colspec>, the element that provides information about the columns in a <table> element. The column specifications are defined using the colname (the name of the column), colnum (the order in which the column appears), and colwidth (the relative width of the column) attributes.
<thead>, the container element for the header in a <table> element. The <thead> element can contain one or more <row> elements and is optional.
<tbody>, the container element for the body rows in a <table> element. The <tbody> element can contain one or more <row> elements.
<row>, the container element for a row of cells in a <table> element. The <row> element contains one or more <entry> elements.

, the container element for a single cell in a element. The element contains the text of a cell in the
element, which should be wrapped in a

element according to best practice.

lcInstruction.p: This lesson will cover the basics of using the <simpletable> and <table> elements. To highlight the differences between these types of tables, the same content will be used for both examples.

fig.title: Example <simpletable> and <table> in a visual format

lcInstruction.draft-comment: replace image with one that's easier to see
lcInstruction.p: Continue using the file l_concept_images_tables_start.dita to add the <simpletable> and <table> elements.
lcInstruction.note: If you are using a DITA editor, some child elements of the <simpletable> and <table> elements will automatically be inserted as you work through the examples.

step.cmd: Inside the <conbody> element after the <fig> element, add a <simpletable> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_images_tables"> <title>Duckling growth and development</title> <conbody> ... </fig> <simpletable> </simpletable> </conbody> </concept>

step.cmd: Inside the <simpletable> element, add the <sthead> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE concept PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DITA Concept//EN" "concept.dtd"> <concept id="concept_images_tables"> <title>Duckling growth and development</title> <conbody> ... <simpletable> <sthead> </sthead> </simpletable> </conbody> </concept>

step.info: The <sthead> element sets up the header row of the <simpletable> element.

step.cmd: Inside the <sthead> element, add two <stentry> elements and populate them as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Duckling growth and development ...

Age

Milestone

step.info: The <stentry> element represents a single cell. The number of <stentry> elements inside the <sthead> element will determine how many columns will be in your <simpletable> element.

Each element you added follows the best practice of wrapping a

element around the text.

step.cmd: After the <sthead> element, add the <strow> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Duckling growth and development ...

Age

Milestone

step.info: The <strow> element sets up each body row following the header row of the <simpletable> element.

step.cmd: Inside the <strow> element, add two <stentry> elements and populate them as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Duckling growth and development ...

Age

Milestone

7 weeks

Attempt flight for the first time

step.info: To avoid rows with missing cells at the end, the <strow> element in a <simpletable> element should contain the same number of <stentry> elements as the <sthead> element.

step.cmd: After the first <strow> element, add two more rows to the <simpletable> element and populate them as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Duckling growth and development ...

Age

Milestone

7 weeks

Attempt flight for the first time

12-14 weeks

Reach adult body weight

1 year

Capable of reproduction

step.info: You can add as many <strow> elements as you wish to a <simpletable> element.

step.cmd: After the <simpletable> element, add a <table> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ...

step.cmd: Inside the <table> element, add a <title> element and populate it as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

step.info: The <title> element is optional, but it allows you to add context to your table, just as it does for images when used inside the <fig> element.

step.cmd: After the <title> element, add the <tgroup> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

step.info: The <tgroup> element contains the body of the table. The number of table columns is set inside the <tgroup> element using the cols attribute. In the example you added, cols="2" shows that this table will contain two columns.
A single <table> element can contain more than one <tgroup> element, which is useful if you need to show more than one table with different headers or numbers of columns under the same title.

step.cmd: Inside the <tgroup> element, add two <colspec> elements and populate them as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

step.info: The <colspec> element sets up your table columns and allows you to specify certain information about them using attributes. In the example you added, the colname attribute was used to name your columns "c1" and "c2" and the colnum attribute was used to designate the order in which these columns appear.

The optional colwidth attribute can be used to control the proportions of the column widths. In the example you added, the colwidth attribute is the same for each column, meaning that they will display at equal widths.

step.cmd: After the last <colspec> element, add the <thead> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

step.info: The <thead> element contains the elements associated with the table header. Unlike the <sthead> element in a <simpletable> element, the <thead> element in a <table> element can contain more than one header row.

step.cmd: Inside the <thead> element, add the <row> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre: Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

step.info: The <row> element contains the elements associated with a table row.

step.cmd: Inside the <row> element, add two <entry> elements and populate them as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

Age

Milestone

step.info:
Each element corresponds to a single table cell in a row. In the example you added, each element follows the best practice of wrapping a

element surrounding the text.

step.cmd: After the <thead> element, add the <tbody> element as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

Age

Milestone

step.info: The <tbody> element is for the main body of the table. Following the same structure as the <thead> element, the <tbody> element can contain <row> elements with <entry> elements inside them.

step.cmd: Inside the <tbody> element, add a <row> element and populate it with <entry> elements and their containing text as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

Age

Milestone

7 weeks

Attempt flight for the first time

step.cmd: After the <row> element you just added, add two more rows and populate them as shown in the following example:

stepxmp.pre:
Duckling growth and development ... Typical development of mallard ducks

Age

Milestone

7 weeks

Attempt flight for the first time

12-14 weeks

Reach adult body weight

1 year

Capable of reproduction

step.info: You can add as many <row> elements as you wish inside the <tbody> element of a table.
Video: Creating a table in DITA
